DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

Japanese PM Abe is considering a cabinet reshuffle in early October. (Kyodo)


UK/EU

EU's Chief Negotiator Barnier said getting a Brexit deal is "realistic" in 6 to 8 weeks. Furthermore, Barnier had earlier tweeted he had a good meeting with Slovenian PM designate in regards of an update on final stages of Brexit negotiations and added they were both united on EU core principles and determined to work hard for an orderly withdrawal of the UK. (Newswires)

UK Government spokesperson said the UK has had a positive engagement with the EU Leaders, focusing on getting a deal by October and the Chequers plan is the only one on the table.  Elsewhere, there were also earlier comments by PM May spokesman that a "no deal" meeting will be held on Thursday. (Newswires)

EU leaders are expected to announce next week that an extraordinary Brexit summit will take place in November. (The Guardian)


COMMODITIES

NHC said Hurricane Florence has become a category four hurricane which is up from a category three, while NHC later commented that further strengthening is anticipated and that Florence is forecast to be an extremely dangerous major hurricane through Thursday. (Newswires)
 

US

Fed's Bostic (voter, dove) said the Fed is designed to be independent from short-term politics and that once we get to neutral, the Fed should wait and see. Bostic added that trade disputes have caused uncertainties among businesses which have been pausing investment plans until the trade landscape had more clarity, while he also suggested that inflation may begin to tick up due to the impact from tariffs. (Newswires)

US House GOP release plan for the 2nd round of tax cuts which includes making lower individual rates permanent. (Newswires)

US Trade Representative Lightizer said talks with EU's Malmström were constructive and the two will meet again at the end of the month. (Newswires)
 

MARKET RECAP

Stock traders were content to ignore the latest trade threats from US President Trump, who on Friday threatened a further round of tariffs on China. Supporting the equity complex was news that Republicans are set to unveil a fresh round of tax cuts this week ahead of midterms in November. After trading flat in APAC trade, stock futures caught a bid as European day got underway, with positive news out of Italy driving its banking sector higher, along with some positive commentary on the Brexit front. The E-mini S&P 500 and ticked up to 2890 before running out of steam. Analysts at Goldman Sachs say that from a technical perspective, short-term support lies at 2,873-2,864, adding that a break below opens potential for 2,831, adding that it shouldn’t really retrace much further than there. Those levels tended to hold up in the US afternoon, when stocks took a dip, before seeing some positive ticks as the closing bell approached. SPX +0.2% AT 2877, DJIA -0.2% AT 25859, NDX +0.2% AT 7448.

The curve was mixed, with traders eyeing this week’s supply, which will generate USD 49bln in new cash. The front end of the curve saw modest selling, pushing 2-year yields to fresh decade highs; the long-end continues to find haven buyers with continuing concerns lingering regarding trade wars. Treasuries also moved lower in sympathy with the bund as the Italian economy minister made the right noises regarding the upcoming budget. But other than that, the T-Note was largely rangebound, with little by way of news to shake it out of its slumber. US T-note futures (Z8) settled half-a-tick higher at 120-21.

US Market Wrap - 11 Sep 2018: EU’s Barnier says Brexit deal could be wrapped in 6-8 weeks
content:
To download the report, please click here. If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

* SNAP-SHOT: Equities mixed, Treasuries flat, crude mixed, dollar down.
* REAR-VIEW: Republicans target more tax cuts; Barnier continues to sound positive on Brexit.
* COMING-UP: German ZEW; UK labour market; US wholesale inventories, JOLTs; API inventories; 3-year auction.

* TAX CUTS: House Republicans are set to unveil another round of tax cuts this week ahead of the November midterms. Already, however, political analysts have suggested that the House GOP could face obstacles in enacting any further cuts, since lawmakers are reportedly reticent to add to the already ballooning budget deficit. Additionally, if successful in the House, the legislation would not likely be taken up in the Senate soon, Reuters reported.

* BREXIT: The FT reports that the EU is preparing to give Brexit negotiator Barnier instructions to close a deal with the UK, which would essentially mean handing him a mandate to speed up the process and settle the Article 50 exit from the EU Barnier is expected to be given this mandate at the 20 September unofficial Brexit conference in Salzburg. The report comes and further news reports over the weekend highlighting splits in the Conservative party, where PM May's Chequers plan is likely to be voted against by around 80 Tory MPs - it is worth making the distinction that although this is enough to derail her agenda, it still is short of the 160 Conservative MPs needed to force May out. The Party conference at the end of September will, therefore, be a key factor. Later, EU's Barnier noted the constructive talks, and suggested a deal could be reached within 6-8 weeks. The Guardian reported that the EU is preparing to announce an emergency summit in November. 

* FED: Fed's Bostic, who has spoken extensively as of late, didn't make any interesting policy comments, but again defended the Fed's independence, pointing out that the central bank was designed to be independent of short-term politics. Bostic also added that trade disputes have caused uncertainties among businesses, who have been pausing investment plans until the trade landscape had more clarity. Bostic also argued that inflation may begin to tick up due to the impact from tariffs O rate hikes, Bostic said that when the Fed has raised rates to neutral, it should assess the situation then. 

* SPX +0.2% AT 2877, DJIA -0.2% AT 25859, NDX +0.2% AT 7448; SECTORS: ENERGY -0.0%, MATERIALS +0.1%, INDUSTRIALS +0.5%, CONSUMER DISC +0.4%, CONSUMER STAP +0.4%, HEALTHCARE -0.3%, FINANCIALS -0.1%, IT +0.3%, TELECOMS +0.5%, UTILITIES +0.6%: Stock traders were content to ignore the latest trade threats from US President Trump, who on Friday threatened a further round of tariffs on China. Supporting the equity complex was news that Republicans are set to unveil a fresh round of tax cuts this week ahead of midterms in November. After trading flat in APAC trade, stock futures caught a bid as European day got underway, with positive news out of Italy driving its banking sector higher, along with some positive commentary on the Brexit front. The E-mini S&P 500 and ticked up to 2890 before running out of steam. Analysts at Goldman Sachs say that from a technical perspective, short-term support lies at 2,873-2,864, adding that a break below opens potential for 2,831, adding that it shouldn’t really retrace much further than there. Those levels tended to hold up in the US afternoon, when stocks took a dip, before seeing some positive ticks as the closing bell approached.  

* STOCK SPECIFICS. CBS (CBS) traded as much as 3% lower following its settlement with National Amusements and CEO Moonves’ departure, which also meant that CBS would not pursue Viacom (VIAB). Tesla (TSLA) after Baird upgraded the automaker, arguing strong fundamentals could push up the stock ahead of its next earnings report. Alibaba (BABA) fell on Chairman/Founder Jack Ma announcing he will step down in 2019. AMD (AMD), Amazon (AMZN) and Footlocker (FL) pushed higher following upgrades at Wells Fargo. United Rentals (URI) announced the acquisition of BlueLine Rental for USD 2.1bln. Nike (NKE) was up after Wedbush said it sees higher sales growth and margin expansion, and NKE has now erased its losses incurred following its new .

* WTI (V8) SETTLES 21 CENTS LOWER AT $67.54/BBL; BRENT (X8) SETTLES 54 CENTS HIGHER AT $77.37: Brent was bid after the Libyan NOC HQ was attacked by militants, though the situation was resolved and the NOC's chairman said there was no impact on output, which took some of the air out of the bid. Brent also found support from a delayed restart of operations at the Buzzard field in the North Sea due to weather conditions. On the note of weather, the US East Coast is bracing for impact from Hurricane Florence (now a cat 4). Analysts at Citi noted that while there is no crude oil production or significant refineries in the storm's path, the possible closure of the Colonial Pipeline could widen the spread between Houston and NY Harbour prices for products. On the demand front, China, the world's largest importer of crude, raises imports to a four-month high in August to 9.04mln BPD, and this came as smaller independent refiners boosted their crude intakes from multi-month lows, PVM said. 

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLE HALF-A-TICK HIGHER AT 120-21: The curve was mixed, with traders eyeing this week’s supply, which will generate USD 49bln in new cash. The front end of the curve saw modest selling, pushing 2-year yields to fresh decade highs; the long-end continues to find haven buyers with continuing concerns lingering regarding trade wars. Treasuries also moved lower in sympathy with the bund as the Italian economy minister made the right noises regarding the upcoming budget. But other than that, the T-Note was largely rangebound, with little by way of news to shake it out of its slumber.

* 3-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW: The US Treasury will auction USD 73bln in 3s (USD 35bln, Tuesday), 10s (USD 23bln on Wednesday) and 30s (USD 15bln on Thursday); with USD 24bln maturing at he month-end settlement, the auctions will raise a net USD 49bln in new cash, according to TD Securities. The Fed will allow all USD 19bn maturing at month-end (the amount is below the $24bn cap) to run off at month-end. Analysts art Barclays have noted that demand has been easing in the 3-year sector since the start of the year, which has seen bid/cover ratios decline from 3.13x in January, to 2.51x at the auction in July. The bank still notes, however, that the August refunding had an uptick, with the metric ticking up, though still lags August 2017 levels. Barclays also notes that performance was also stronger at the start of the year, with most of the sales clearing the WI level. But July and August's auctions saw tails of 0.6bps and 0.2bps respectively. Foreign participation has been steadily ticking down this year, too from highs around 20% in February, to a low of 6% in July. Domestic investors remain active, however, and raised participation in July. Focussing on this week's 3s auction, TD Securities says that following a dsolid NFP release on Friday, yields in the short-end have nudged higher, which should help set-up going into the auction. 

* USD: The buck is slightly softer on Monday, and hasn't strengthened too much after Trump's threats on Friday to potentially unleash further tariffs on China. The DXY trades a touch above 95.00. While some bank desks have been talking up the USD in an escalating China trade war scenario, the team and ING are more sceptical, arguing that trade war escalation will not be positive for the USD, which it says has been buoyed by cyclical US economic sentiment and related portfolio inflows. "These would go into reverse if the US and China slap further tariffs on each other – and we prefer to play this via short USD/JPY positions," ING says. Last week, Goldman Sachs also argued that short USDJPY was a way to play an escalation of the China trade war theme. 

* GBP: Once again, positive Brexit headlines cast a shadow over everything else sterling-related; The Europeans seem to be making the right noises about a Brexit deal, and that means traders can focus on the positives, shrugging-off the political woes faced by UK PM May. A solid GDP print was largely ignored, though provided another reason to be optimistic on GBP. 1.30 was breached to the upside, helped along by weakness in the USD; EURGBP's fall was more benign, by comparison, briefly breached 0.89 to the downside, though seems content to take a breater at that level. This week's BOE is likely to be a snooze fest, with markets focussed on Brexit headlines and UK politics. 

* JPY, CHF: The major laggards all day, albeit with the former deriving some underlying support from upward revisions to Q2 Japanese growth and not extending losses vs the Greenback much beyond 111.00. However, the Franc almost weakened to 0.9750 and recoiled around 1 big figure vs the Eur from 1.1200+ to just shy of 1.1300, with no obvious fundamental driver, but the price moves smack of some form of official action.

* AUD, NZD, CAD: All benefiting from the Gbp/Brexit-related US Dollar downturn (DXY unwinding NFP-inspired gains from 95.500+ towards 95.000), with the Aud consolidating its rebound from 0.7200, the Kiwi nudging 0.6550 vs close to 0.6500 at one stage overnight and the Loonie bouncing further from near 1.3200 lows towards 1.3150 having cleared the 100 HMA (1.3171).

* SCANDIS: Some NOK outperformance vs the EUR (tested 9.6950) and SEK on stronger than expected Norwegian CPI that keeps the Norges Bank on track to tighten well before the ECB and Riksbank, but the Swedish Krona still held up relatively well after Sunday’s inconclusive election result, as the SD party did not attain as many votes as predicted in some polls – Eur/Sek sub-10.5000.   

* EM: A volatile start to the week with the Lira and Rouble unwinding a degree of CBRT and CBR rate hike premium ahead of respective policy meetings, while the Rand was undermined by more political angst and positioning for possible ratings downgrades. Usd/Try is currently around 6.4500, Usd/Rub above 70.0000 and Usd/Zar 15.2000. Elsewhere, the Yuan came under renewed pressure after Friday’s warning from US President Trump that the pending $200 bn tariffs on Chinese goods could yet be more than doubled.

content:
GBP

Sterling is ending a rather manic EU session on the front foot, having largely ignored a mixed batch of UK data and survived an early 1.2900 downside test vs the Usd, with latest Brexit headlines the clear catalyst. EU chief negotiator Barnier claims that it is realistic to reach a deal within 6-8 weeks, and the 2 sides are close to agreement on security, propelling Cable from circa 1.2950 through 1.3000 initially before stops around 1.3020 were tripped to a fresh peak for September near 1.3050 before momentum faded. Meanwhile, EUR/Gbp retreated from 0.8950+ to just under 0.8900 at one stage, as the single currency struggled to clear 1.1600 again, with latest CFTC data revealing a spec shift to net Eur longs and so the positional base prone to long liquidation again. content:

If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.

  • CBS (CBS) – The broadcaster’s board has announced a settlement that ends its litigation with controlling shareholder, National Amusements and severs ties with CEO Moonves.
  • SAIC (SAIC) – The tech co. is to acquire Engility in an all-stock deal at USD 2.5bln.
  • Alibaba (BABA) – Chairman and founder Jack Ma announced he will be stepping down on September 10th 2019.

10th September 2018

DOW JONES

  • Amazon (AMZN) – The co. is said to be opening an Amazon Go store in New York, this follows the launch of its Seattle based store. (Newswires)
  • Apple (AAPL) – President Trump has told AAPL to make products in the U.S. to avoid tariffs. Separately, the co. has removed Alex Jones’s Infowars from its App Store after ‘violating its app-developer guidelines’. Elsewhere, the tech giant has had its price target raised to USD 256 from USD 220 at Loop Capital. (Newswires)
  • Boeing (BA) – The industrial has announced an investment in Denver-based BridgeSat, an optical communications solutions co. which is building a network of ground stations to send large amounts of data into space quickly and reliably. (Newswires)
  • Goldman Sachs (GS) – Saudi Arabia’s Public Investment Fund has chosen the bank to advise on the sale of its stake in the petrochemicals co., Saudi Basic Industries, to state oil co. Saudi Aramco. (Newswires)
  • United Technologies (UTX) – The aircraft co. has won a USD 437mln modification to a contract for flight-weight adaptive engines for the U.S. Air Force. (Newswires)  
  • Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) – The co. is said to be purchasing pharmacy files of 185 Fred’s Pharmacies (FRED) across the southeast U.S. for USD 165mln. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • American International Group (AIG) – The insurance co.’s CEO Duperreault is said to be plotting the firm’s revival by returning to basics. He is looking to allow business heads to establish their own budgets and performance goals. (Newswires)
  • Campbell Soup (CPB) – The co.’s board is creating a list of CEO candidates to avoid Third Point’s proxy challenge; COO Luca Mignini is the most likely internal candidate. (Newswires)
  • CBS (CBS) – The broadcaster’s board has announced a settlement that ends its litigation with controlling shareholder, National Amusements (NAI) and severs ties with CEO Leslie Moonves. Moonves has resigned as six more woman accused him of sexual misconduct. National Amusements confirmed Sunday evening that it has no plans for a merger with Viacom (VIAB) for at least two years and then only if two third of directors affiliated with NAI have requested that it do so. (Newswires)
  • CVS Health (CVS) – The union Teamsters Local 727 has filed an unfair labour practice against CVS after the co. used delay tactics and didn’t provide dates to the union for negotiators. (Newswires)
  • Ford Motor (F) – President Trump said that Ford’s dropping of its plan to sell Chinese-made cars is “just the beginning”. (Newswires)
  • Merck & Co. (MRK) – The European Commission has approved the co.’s anti-PD-1 therapy, Keytruda, for the first-line treatment of metastatic nonsquamous non-small cell lung cancer in adults. (Newswires)
  • Raytheon (RTN) – The aerospace co. has expanded its relationship with commercial small satellite co., HawkEye 360, to provide greater commercial tech and precise data to the government. (Newswires)
  • State Street (STT) – The asset manager has announced the opening of its first office in Abu Dhabi as it expands its Middle East presence. (Newswires)
  • United Rentals (URI) – The equipment rental co. is to acquire BlueLine Rental for USD 2.1bln. (Newswires)
  • Viacom (VIAB) – Barron’s said in their weekly issue that VIAB is worth buying as its chief Robert Bakish is working to put television assets to better use and following Moonves’ departure from CBS (CBS), there remains a chance of a merge between the two co.s. (Newswires)

NASDAQ 100

  • Facebook (FB) – The French based internet advertising co., Criteo (CRTO), said that following its change in partner status with FB it still will continue to work with them. (Newswires)
  • Tesla (TSLA) – The electric automaker has begun delivery of its Model 3s on a “first come, first serve” basis. CEO, Elon Musk, sent out an email to his employees to ignore the “fuss and noise” in the media and focus on the results as he says Tesla is about to have “the most amazing quarter in our history”. Needham reiterated TSLA as Underperform, Bernstein says the recent selloff could be used as an entry point and Baird named Tesla a ‘Fresh Pick’ ahead of Q3 deliveries. Jerome Guillen has been promoted to President of Automotive Operations. (Newswires)
  • Ulta Beauty (ULTA) – The cosmetics co. is trading higher pre-market after it had its price target raised to USD 340 from USD 280 by Oppenheimer analyst Rupesh Parikh. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Alibaba (BABA) – Chairman and founder Jack Ma announced he will be stepping down on September 10th 2019. CEO Daniel Zhang will succeed as chairman and Ma will stay for the next year to make sure the transition is smooth. Ma is set to go into the teaching profession following his retirement. (Newswires)
  • Alkermes (ALKS) – The pharma co. has expanded its phase 1 study for ALKS 4230, an immune-oncology drug, to evaluate its safety and anti-tumour activity when administered with the PD-1 inhibitor Keytruda in patients with advanced solid tumours. (Newswires)
  • NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) – Executive VP, Kurt Sievers, has been promoted to President in attempts to improve the leadership team to better align with the co.’s growth strategy. Guido Dierick will retire as Executive VP after a 36-year career in the industry. (Newswires)
  • SAIC (SAIC) – The tech co. is to acquire Engility in an all-stock deal at USD 2.5bln. (Newswires)
  • Semtech (SMTC) – Pipper Jaffray analyst says that semiconductor demand remains strong as the sector faces little impact from trade tensions. Kumar says SMTC and Integrated Device Technology (IDTI) have the best organic growth stories and has raised SMTC’s price target to USD 63 from USD 57. (Newswires)
  • Snap (SNAP) – The social media co.’s Chief Strategy Officer Imran Khan is stepping down to pursue other opportunities. (Newswires)

subject: EU DEBT UPDATE: core bonds more divergent
content: It’s been a gradual move, but nevertheless quite apparent as UK debt continues to rebound from worst levels and just retested early Liffe intraday highs of 122.18 (+7 ticks vs -31 ticks at one stage), while Bunds remain in negative territory, albeit off 159.52 Eurex lows (-43 ticks vs +15 ticks at best). Hence, 10 year spreads are converging as Brexit uncertainty rumbles on and the German benchmark remains conscious of the bid in BTPs (even though paring some gains).

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 10th September 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • BTPs strengthening on increased Italian budget confidence
  • European equities marginally higher with FTSE MIB outperforming; FX majors seeing choppy trade
  • Looking ahead the highlight is Fed’s Bostic

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week mostly subdued following the lacklustre performance on Wall St last Friday where sentiment was dampened after Trump doubled-down on his tariff threats against China, while participants also digested a slew of key data including US NFP, Chinese Trade Data and Japanese GDP. ASX 200 (Unch.) was flat as strength in tech and healthcare was counterbalanced by weakness in financials heading into a fresh round of grilling by the banking royal commission, while Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) was choppy amid similar indecision in the local currency and with mild support seen following a stronger than expected upward revision in the Final Annualized Q2 GDP data. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.6%) underperformed after further tariff threats from US President Trump and as participants digested mixed trade data in which Trade Balance and Exports missed expectations. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with price action subdued despite the indecisive risk tone and BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 1.1tln in 1yr-10yr JGBs.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8389 (Prev. 6.8212)


Chinese Trade Balance (USD)(Aug) 27.91B vs. Exp. 31.79B (Prev. 28.05B). (Newswires)
Chinese Exports (Aug) Y/Y 9.8% vs. Exp. 10.1% (Prev. 12.2%)

Chinese Imports (Aug) Y/Y 20% vs. Exp. 18.7% (Prev. 27.3%)

Chinese Foreign Reserves (USD)(Aug) 3.110T vs. Exp. 3.115T (Prev. 3.118T)

Chinese CPI (Jul) Y/Y 2.3% vs. Exp. 2.2% (Prev. 2.1%). (Newswires)

Chinese PPI (Jul) Y/Y 4.1% vs. Exp. 4.0% (Prev. 4.6%)

Japanese GDP (Q2 F) Q/Q 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 0.5%). (Newswires)

Japanese GDP Annualised (Q2 F) 3.0% vs. Exp. 2.6% (Prev. 1.9%)

EU/UK/US

UK GDP Estimate YY (Jul) 1.6% vs. Exp. 1.4% (Prev. 1.3%)

UK GDP Estimate MM (Jul) 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.1%)

UK GDP Est 3M/3M (Jul) 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.4%)

EU are reportedly preparing to give instructions to EU Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier to help achieve a Brexit deal. (FT)

A draft Brexit plan proposed by Eurosceptics in the Conservative party includes significant tax cuts, a new military expeditionary and a domestic-built missile defence system, according to leaked documents, thus confirming expectations for the proposal of a Canada-style trade deal. This would go against the proposals made in the Chequer’s agreement, with the article suggesting that if the new proposals were rejected, Eurosecptics would prefer to leave with EU without a deal, on WTO terms. As a guide, Jacob Rees-Mogg is due to speak on Tuesday. (Guardian)

Former UK Foreign Secretary Johnson attacked UK PM May's Chequers plan, which he described as the PM "wrapped a suicide vest" around the British constitution and "handed the detonator" to Brussels. (BBC) Allies of Johnson have accused Downing Street of a smear campaign to discredit him. (Times)

Sweden election early results showed the governing Social Democrats and its centre-left bloc with 40.6% of votes vs. the centre-right alliance with 40.1% of votes, while the Sweden Democrats which are the nationalist anti-immigration party were seen to receive 17.8% of votes. Sweden Democrat leader Akesson commented he is prepared to talk with all other parties especially with centre-right leader Kristersson, while the leader of the Sweden Liberal Party (part of centre-right bloc) said they want an alliance government but it will not happen by cooperating with the Sweden Democrats. There were also comments from Swedish PM and Social Democrat party leader Lofven that nothing would be determined by the election night and that he will continue to work as PM until parliament vote, while he also stated this should be the end for bloc politics regardless of the final outcome. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

US officials stated Syrian President Assad has approved gas attack in Idlib, while reports added that Trump has not decided whether to target Iranian or Russian forces aiding Assad. (WSJ)

North Korea held a military parade for the 70th anniversary of its Foundation Day in which no ICBMs were displayed and North Korean Leader Kim refrained from delivering a speech. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed's Rosengren (non-voter, hawk) says strengthening economy will likely need mildly restrictive policy and he would not be surprised if Fed forecasts for neutral rate and rate path shift upwards, adds no need to quicken pace of hikes & inflation justifies continued hikes. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities are marginally higher (Eurostoxx 50 +0.4%) with Italy’s FTSE MIB outperforming its peers as the Italian banks benefit from recent BTP price action. Mediobanca (+7.0%), Banco BPM (+5.6%) and Intesa Sanpaolo (+5.0%) all stand at the top of the index. In terms of sectors, utility names outperform while underperformance is seen across material names due to the weaker base metal prices. In terms of individual stocks, Swiss listed Richemont (+1.4%) appointed a new Chief Executive after the company ran without a CEO for almost two years. Richemont also reported 5-month sale figures which dragged up rival watchmaker Swatch (+1.1%) in sympathy.  Over in Italy, Leonardo (+4.7%) shares are higher after reports the company is in talks with other buyers for the remaining ATR planes tied in a EUR 1bln deal with Iran (which cannot be delivered due to sanctions)

FX

DXY - Volatile price action in the index and broad Dollar, between 95.570-297 parameters, as an early EU advance was quickly reversed amidst buy/sell orders in some pairings ahead of major technical levels, data and positioning for potentially pivotal events.

AUD/GBP/EUR - Relatively firm within the G10 community, or to be precise all recovering well from bouts of downside pressure with the Aud finding support overnight around 0.7100, Cable bouncing firmly from circa 1.2900 and the single currency finding traction after reports of heavy buying at 1.1525 (just above 1.1518 technical support and stops said to be in place below 1.1520). Note also, a very big option expiry at the 1.1500 strike (2.1 bn) may have impacted price action as the headline pair rebounds towards 1.1600.

CHF - The marked underperformer, and possibly due to official intervention following rallies through 0.9700 vs the Greenback and 1.1200 against the Eur.

NOK/SEK - Firmer than forecast Norwegian inflation data has boosted the Nok to test resistance vs the Eur around 9.7000 and not far from chart support at 9.6950, while the Sek is holding up well in wake of Sunday’s Swedish election that looks set to leave the main parties short of enough votes to form a Government, but the far right SD not claiming as much as many anticipated – hence, Eur/Sek pivoting around 10.4500 and somewhat relieved.

NZD/CAD/JPY - All narrowly mixed vs the Usd, with the Kiwi hovering above 0.6500 after mixed NZ manufacturing data overnight, the Loonie keeping its head just above 1.3200 amidst more mainly positive NAFTA negotiation updates (but still no sign of timing on a deal) and Jpy probing either side of 111.00 in wake of upgrades to Japanese Q2 GDP.

EM - Contrasting fortunes for regional currencies, with the Lira and Rand at opposite ends of the spectrum after Turkish Q2 GDP slowed sharply and reports circulated that Lula could be behind an ANC plot to oust current SA President Ramaphosa. Usd/Try is off recent lows and almost hit 6.5000 again, even though expectations are running high for aggressive CBRT action on Thursday, while Usd/Zar has retreated from 15.3000+ in contrast. Elsewhere, Usd/Rub is holding just below 70.0000 in the run up to Friday’s CBR policy meeting with markets also looking for a hike.

FIXED INCOME

The 10-year UK benchmark has bounced off 121.80 lows in wake of the domestic deluge of releases that pretty much offset in terms of actuals vs consensus, though with a net skew to the downside if anything. However, regaining 122.00 looks a stretch too far given ongoing weakness in Bunds vs BTP strength with fresh intraday troughs and peaks posted recently at 159.52 and 125.80 respectively, and the former only just breached in above technical support at 159.59, with no technical levels to the downside until 159.00 the figure. Elsewhere, US Treasuries are essentially flat and side-lined after last Friday’s jobs data declines and a relatively sparse calendar ahead.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures continue to edge higher in European trade with the former eyeing USD 68.50/bbl to the upside with recent gains in the complex attributed to ongoing hurricane season. NHC reported Florence continues to strengthen rapidly and is expected to become a major hurricane soon, the hurricane is expected to remain an extremely dangerous major hurricane as it is expected to hit land on Thursday. Traders will be also mindful of events in Libya where there has been a shooting incident at the NOC headquarters in Tripoli. Over in the North Sea, the Buzzard oilfield did not restart operations as planned over the weekend, operations should restart on Monday.

Elsewhere, gold marginally nurses post-NFP losses as the greenback eases off highs, while copper is kept lacklustre by the ongoing trade concerns and underperformance in China.

Gilts and Short Sterling futures: jittery trade ahead of UK data raft
content: The UK STIR strip has been erring towards the side of caution, albeit marginally, since its return to Liffe, but the 10 year debt future opened a few ticks above last Friday’s 122.11 settlement level and briefly nudged up to 122.18 before reversing course alongside Bunds to a 121.89 low (-22 ticks), as Italian bonds extend gains on renewed optimism if not faith that the regime in Rome will stick to the EU fiscal script rather that flouting budget rules. Note, 10 year BTPs have now been as high as 125.63, +130 ticks vs their German peer down to 159.66, -29 ticks. Back to Liffe, Gilts and Short Sterling contracts will get a heavy dose of domestic data to trade off with ONS GDP, ip and trade all scheduled ahead of NIESR GDP, and ahead of jobs/earnings and CPI before Thursday’s BoE.

content: A mostly firmer start to Monday’s Eurex session with the 10 year German benchmark straddling the 160.00 marker in a 159.93-160.10 range vs its previous 159.95 close, and displaying some resistance in the face of another upturn in Italian BTPs that are testing offers ahead of 125.00. On the flip-side, broad risk sentiment remains fragile as US President Trump ratchets up his trade offensive against China via an additional $270 bn import tariffs on top of the $200 bn that could be imposed in short order, and raising the total to $250 bn. On the regional data front, not much on the agenda aside from the September Sentix Index that is forecast to remain relatively stable.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

10th September 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week mostly subdued following the lacklustre performance on Wall St last Friday where sentiment was dampened after Trump doubled-down on his tariff threats against China, while participants also digested a slew of key data including US NFP, Chinese Trade Data and Japanese GDP. ASX 200 (Unch.) was flat as strength in tech and healthcare was counterbalanced by weakness in financials heading into a fresh round of grilling by the banking royal commission, while Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) was choppy amid similar indecision in the local currency and with mild support seen following a stronger than expected upward revision in the Final Annualized Q2 GDP data. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.6%) underperformed after further tariff threats from US President Trump and as participants digested mixed trade data in which Trade Balance and Exports missed expectations.

FTSE

Ryanair (RYA LN) – Seven unions representing cabin crew, pilots and ground-handling staff from across Europe (Italy, Portugal, Belgium, Spain and the Netherlands) threatened Co. with a concerted strike by month-end if shareholders do not oust Co.’s directors. The unions added a strike announcement will come no later than September 13th. (FT)

Sainsbury’s (SBRY LN) – Co. acknowledged UK CMA could dent Co’s proposed merger with Asda. UK CMA could announce as soon as this week that it will proceed directly to an in-depth probe of the transaction. (FT)

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 10th September 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets began the week mostly subdued following the lacklustre performance on Wall St last Friday after Trump doubled-down on his tariff threats against China
  • In FX, EUR/USD and GBP/USD contained, while AUD/USD and NZD/USD eye a test on the 0.7100 and 0.6500 levels to the downside respectively
  • EU are reportedly preparing to give instructions to EU Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier to help achieve a Brexit deal. Meanwhile, Eurosceptic proposals have been leaked to UK press
  • SEK indecisive amid political uncertainty after the governing Social Democrats and its centre-left coalition were at a deadlock with the opposition centre-right alliance
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, UK GDP & production figures, Fed’s Bostic

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week mostly subdued following the lacklustre performance on Wall St last Friday where sentiment was dampened after Trump doubled-down on his tariff threats against China, while participants also digested a slew of key data including US NFP, Chinese Trade Data and Japanese GDP. ASX 200 (Unch.) was flat as strength in tech and healthcare was counterbalanced by weakness in financials heading into a fresh round of grilling by the banking royal commission, while Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) was choppy amid similar indecision in the local currency and with mild support seen following a stronger than expected upward revision in the Final Annualized Q2 GDP data. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.6%) underperformed after further tariff threats from US President Trump and as participants digested mixed trade data in which Trade Balance and Exports missed expectations. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with price action subdued despite the indecisive risk tone and BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 1.1tln in 1yr-10yr JGBs.

US President Trump said on Friday that another USD 276bln China tariffs are ready to go added to the USD 200bln and that the fresh tariffs could be available on short notice, while he also commented that the USD 200bln in tariffs could be announced soon, depending on what happens. In addition, Trump stated the US is starting trade negotiations with Japan and that Japan knows it's a big deal if they don't make a deal. (Newswires)

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8389 (Prev. 6.8212)


Chinese Trade Balance (USD)(Aug) 27.91B vs. Exp. 31.79B (Prev. 28.05B). (Newswires)
Chinese Exports (Aug) Y/Y 9.8% vs. Exp. 10.1% (Prev. 12.2%)

Chinese Imports (Aug) Y/Y 20% vs. Exp. 18.7% (Prev. 27.3%)

Chinese Foreign Reserves (USD)(Aug) 3.110T vs. Exp. 3.115T (Prev. 3.118T)

Chinese CPI (Jul) Y/Y 2.3% vs. Exp. 2.2% (Prev. 2.1%). (Newswires)

Chinese PPI (Jul) Y/Y 4.1% vs. Exp. 4.0% (Prev. 4.6%)

Japanese GDP (Q2 F) Q/Q 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 0.5%). (Newswires)

Japanese GDP Annualised (Q2 F) 3.0% vs. Exp. 2.6% (Prev. 1.9%)


UK/EU

EU are reportedly preparing to give instructions to EU Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier to help achieve a Brexit deal. (FT)

A draft Brexit plan proposed by Eurosceptics in the Conservative party includes significant tax cuts, a new military expeditionary and a domestic-built missile defence system, according to leaked documents, thus confirming expectations for the proposal of a Canada-style trade deal. This would go against the proposals made in the Chequer’s agreement, with the article suggesting that if the new proposals were rejected, Eurosecptics would prefer to leave with EU without a deal, on WTO terms. As a guide, JacobRees-Mogg is due to speak on Tuesday. (Guardian)

Former UK Foreign Secretary Johnson attacked UK PM May's Chequers plan, which he described as the PM "wrapped a suicide vest" around the British constitution and "handed the detonator" to Brussels. (BBC) Allies of Johnson have accused Downing Street of a smear campaign to discredit him. (Times)

In its first quarterly economic outlook report, KPMG forecasts that UK GDP will grow by 1.4 per cent next year in the event of a good deal, but by only 0.6 per cent in a no-deal scenario. (Times)

Sweden election early results showed the governing Social Democrats and its centre-left bloc with 40.6% of votes vs. the centre-right alliance with 40.1% of votes, while the Sweden Democrats which are the nationalist anti-immigration party were seen to receive 17.8% of votes. Sweden Democrat leader Akesson commented he is prepared to talk with all other parties especially with centre-right leader Kristersson, while the leader of the Sweden Liberal Party (part of centre-right bloc) said they want an alliance government but it will not happen by cooperating with the Sweden Democrats. There were also comments from Swedish PM and Social Democrat party leader Lofven that nothing would be determined by the election night and that he will continue to work as PM until parliament vote, while he also stated this should be the end for bloc politics regardless of the final outcome. (Newswires)


Catalan leader Torra is said to call for a referendum ahead of protests planned by Catalan secessionists during September 11th regional holiday. (Newswires)


FX

In FX markets, the DXY remained above the 95.00 level and near Friday’s highs in the aftermath of the NFP jobs data. This kept price action in EUR/USD and GBP/USD contained, while AUD/USD and NZD/USD eye a test on the 0.7100 and 0.6500 levels to the downside respectively. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was indecisive around 111.00 as the impact from a firmer greenback was nullified by stronger than expected GDP as well as the predominantly risk-averse tone. SEK also traded indecisively amid political uncertainty after the governing Social Democrats and its centre-left coalition were at a deadlock with the opposition centre-right alliance, and with the nationalists, anti-immigration Sweden Democrats effectively the kingmaker.

COMMODITIES

Commodities traded mixed in which WTI crude futured traded higher to reclaim the USD 68.00/bbl amid early strength in energy led by gasoline prices due to the ongoing hurricane season as Florence continued to strengthen and Isaac became the 5th hurricane of the 2018 Atlantic season. Elsewhere, gold marginally extended on losses as the greenback retained its post-NFP gains, while copper was kept lacklustre by the ongoing trade concerns and underperformance in China.
 

Baker Hughes Rig Count (7 Sep): Oil rigs -2 to 860, gas rigs +2 to 186, total rigs unchanged at 1048. (Newswires)

IEA Director Birol said EM crisis may impact oil demand but added that the IEA still expects robust oil production growth and tighter supply. Birol also urged producers to pump more oil to avoid higher prices, while he stated Saudi Arabia still has scope to raise oil output and that he sees more US oil pipeline capacity next year. (Newswires)

US Energy Secretary Perry to meet with Saudi Arabia officials including Energy Minister Al-Falih on Monday. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

US officials stated Syrian President Assad has approved gas attack in Idlib, while reports added that Trump has not decided whether to target Iranian or Russian forces aiding Assad. (WSJ)

North Korea held a military parade for the 70th anniversary of its Foundation Day in which no ICBMs were displayed and North Korean Leader Kim refrained from delivering a speech. (Newswires)
 

US

The T-Note future was sold after a solid NFP print, where AHE rose more than expected, which pushed the future down from 120-04 down to 119-20; newswires reported that there was large put buying interest into the data in the TYZ8 contract. After the data, there was some stabilisation, with the Z8 contract trading between 119-20 to 119-23, though there was a bid after Trump threatened China with further tariffs, but even then, the move was faded as we approached the close. Despite yields higher across the curve, there was some narrowing between major curve spreads (5s30s -3bps, 2s30s -2bps, 2s10s -0.2bps). T-note futures (Z8) settled 17 ticks lower at 119-20+.

Fed's Kaplan (non-voter, neutral) is not worried that raising rates three further times would invert the yield curve but stated an inverted yield curve could be a worry since it may impede credit growth, while Kaplan also commented that the FOMC will not need to make a judgement on whether or not rates will become restrictive until the middle of next year.

Fed's Rosengren (non-voter, hawk) said strengthening economy will likely need mildly restrictive policy and that he would not be surprised if Fed forecasts for neutral rate and rate path shift upwards. Rosengren also commented there is no need to quicken pace of hikes but added that inflation justifies continued hikes. (Newswires)

US President Trump stated on Friday that the US are working on a deal with Canada and "will see if it is good", while he had also commented that Canada is moving along with NAFTA talks and we will see what happens. In related news, Canada's Foreign Minister Freeland said the US and Canada are both committed to work on NAFTA and that talks remain constructive but declined to say whether further NAFTA talks will be needed in the upcoming week. (Newswires)

ASX 200 (+0.1%) is relatively flat as strength in tech and healthcare is counterbalanced by weakness in financials heading into a fresh round of grilling by the banking royal commission, while Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) is choppy around the 22300 level amid similar indecision in the local currency and with mild support seen following a stronger than expected upward revision in the Final Annualized Q2 GDP data. Elsewhere, USD/JPY is indecisive around 111.00 as the impact from a firmer greenback is nullified by stronger than expected GDP as well as the predominantly risk averse tone, while SEK is also indecisive amid political uncertainty after the governing Social Democrats and its centre-left coalition were at a deadlock with the opposition centre-right alliance and with the nationalists, anti-immigration Sweden Democrats effectively the kingmaker.
